title: 115_hr889
content: The Act titled "Human Trafficking Fraud Enforcement Act of 2017" establishes an Office for Tax Law Enforcement related to human trafficking and commercial sex acts. The Secretary of the Treasury will establish an office within the Internal Revenue Service to investigate and prosecute violations of the internal revenue laws related to human trafficking and commercial sex acts as specified in certain criminal provisions. The Secretary of the Treasury will establish an office within the Internal Revenue Service to investigate and prosecute violations of laws related to human trafficking and commercial sex acts. The office will cooperate with the Department of Justice and FBI initiatives. A report on enforcement activities must be submitted to relevant congressional committees within a year of the Act's enactment. The office established under subsection (a) will make recommendations for statutory changes to aid in future prosecutions. Whistleblower awards under the Internal Revenue Code may be given to victims of human trafficking. $4,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2018 for the office, with additional funding as needed. The office established under subsection (a) is authorized to receive appropriations for fiscal years 2018 and 2019 based on tax collections and penalties imposed under the Internal Revenue Code. Any unexpended amounts will be transferred to the Crime Victims Fund. SEC. 3. INCREASE IN CRIMINAL MONETARY PENALTIES. SEC. 3. INCREASE IN CRIMINAL MONETARY PENALTIES. Amendment to Section 7201 of the Internal Revenue Code to increase penalties for attempting to evade or defeat tax related to human trafficking and commercial sex acts. The amendment increases penalties for willful failure to file tax returns, supply information, or pay taxes, specifically related to human trafficking and commercial sex acts. The penalty amount is raised from $25,000 to $50,000. The amendment increases penalties for willful failure to file tax returns, supply information, or pay taxes related to human trafficking and commercial sex acts. It amends the Internal Revenue Code by substituting 'felony' for 'misdemeanor', increasing the penalty amount to $500,000 ($1,000,000), and increasing the imprisonment term to 10 years. Section 7203(a) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to replace "this section" with "this subsection". Section 7206 is also amended to include a new subsection addressing fraud and false statements related to tax from human trafficking and commercial sex acts, increasing penalties to $500,000 ($1,000,000) and imprisonment to 5 years. Section 7206 of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to increase penalties for fraudulent statements or failure to make statements to employees. Penalties may be applied in addition to other penalties. The monetary limitation for underpayment or overpayment of tax due to fraud is also increased. The amendments to the Internal Revenue Code increase penalties for fraudulent actions, with a minimum applicable amount for fraudulent tax shown on a return. Moneys are appropriated to the Crime Victims Fund to assist victims of crime. These amendments apply to actions occurring after the enactment of the Act.
